hi,Tom Emerson,

thanks for your advice.

It seems if I just want the HTML pages,there is only one way to check the 
response HTTP Header,if there is "Content-Type: text/html"	,then save it 
to ARC file ,else ,discard it.

ansi

======= 2004-07-14 13:35:01 =======

>It looks like the actual implementation of content negotiation with
>the 'Accept:' header does not work the way you think it does. I tried
>with various servers (IIS, Apache, and GWS) and they all appear to
>have the same behavior: if the content type of the requested resource
>is a complete mismatch of the Accept: header, the resource is returned
>anyway instead of returning a 406 as the HTTP/1.1 specification would
>imply they should.
>
>That would explain why forcing "Accept: text/html" will still return
>images with a 200 response.
>
>It could also be the case that the individual servers have content
>negotiation turned off, or it is not fully implemented, or...
>
>A quick scan of the Apache 2.0.50 content negotiation module would
>imply that a 406 should be returned.
>
>FWIW, I added the "accept-headers" parameter to the HTML fetcher so I
>could force the Accept-Language header --- I've never used straight
>"Accept:".
>
